measure.description: Percentage of elapsed time spent in JIT compilation since the last JIT compilation phase.
Number of times the generation 0 objects were garbage collected (Gen 0 GC) per interval.
Number of times the generation 1 objects were garbage collected (Gen 1 GC) per interval.
Number of times the generation 2 objects were garbage collected (Gen 2 GC) per interval.
Percentage of elapsed time that was spent on performing a Garbage Collection (GC) since the last GC cycle.
Maximum number of bytes that can be allocated in Generation 0 (Gen 0).
Current number of bytes allocated in Generation 1 (Gen 1).
Current number of bytes allocated in Generation 2 (Gen 2).
Current number of bytes allocated for Large Objects (>20KBytes).
Amount of non-paged memory used by the monitored .NET Process.
Amount of paged memory used by the monitored .NET Process.
The maximum amount of virtual memory that the associated .NET process has requested.
Amount of virtual memory used by the monitored .NET Process.
Percentage of privileged CPU time (time that the process has spent running code inside the operating system core) generated by the monitored .NET Process.
Percentage of total CPU time (time that the process has spent running code inside the operating system core and in user mode) generated by the monitored .NET Process.
Percentage of user CPU time (time that the process has spent running code in user mode) generated by the monitored .NET Process.
The number of threads currently active in this .NET process.

measure.id: Apdex performance zone for Page Actions
measure.description: Application Performance Index performance zone (satisfied, tolerating, frustrated). As defined by apdex.org. Used for Business Transactions.
Provides the user-agent (for example, browser) information of a visit.
Represents the percentage of visits with a single action.
Provides the user-agent (for example, browser) information of a visit. Used for Business Visits.
Represents the number of bytes received by the Web Service.
Represents the number of bytes received by the Web Request.
Represents the number of bytes sent by the Web Service.
Represents the number of bytes sent by the Web Request.

Name of domain where CDN content is loaded from which has most impact on page load time. Used for Business Transactions.
Represents the duration of CDN content during a user action.
Percentage of total time the CPU spent waiting for I/O operations.
Percentage of total time the CPU was in idle mode.
Percentage of time the CPU spent in everything else. This includes steal time, interrupt time, and every unknown time.
Percentage of total time the CPU spent processing system-space programs.
Percentage of total time the CPU was in use.
Percentage of total time the CPU spent processing user-space programs.
Process CPU time spent in system (kernel) mode.
Process CPU time spent in user mode.

Page Faults are not errors per se, they occur when data in the virtualized address space is accessed which is not currently present in the physical memory. A high or rising number is an indicator that more memory is actively in use than the machine has physically available.

incidentrule.description: A prior connected Application Process/Agent was shut down.
Connection to a previously connected Application Process/Agent has been lost.
Raises incidents for individual connected agents.
Session was cleared.
The system profile configuration changed.

Agent automatically disabled its instrumentation. Possible reasons are for example, if there was no Collector reachable when the Agent was started up or overall instrumentation performance on the Collector was too low.

incidentrule.id: High CPU Usage for Application Process
incidentrule.description: Creates an incident when high cpu usage is detected for a longer period.

condition.refmeasure: High CPU Usage for Application Process

incidentrule.id: High GC Activity for Application Process
incidentrule.description: Fires an incident when a high amount of process time is used for garbage collection.

condition.refmeasure: SUD High GC Activity - CPU Utilization
SUD High GC Activity - GC Utilization

incidentrule.id: High Memory Usage for Application Process
incidentrule.description: Memory usage sustained at a high percentage for a longer time period.

condition.refmeasure: High Memory Usage for Application Process

incidentrule.description: Agent disabled CPU time capturing because of too high overhead. Check the agent's CPU time capturing options in the agent group's sensor configuration dialog.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that are corrupted.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have been truncated as their size exceeds the node limit.
Raises incidents for PurePaths that have timed out as either a method has not returned, or a whole child path did not finish within a certain timeout.
Signals performed agent hot sensor placement
Application Process reported Out-of-memory. A Memory Dump will be automatically triggered if not disabled in the Agent group settings.
Continuous transaction recording was aborted.
A test violation (test has degraded/improved/failed, or is volatile) occurred.
Custom user created Incidents.
The overall failed transaction rate exceeds the configured threshold.

incidentrule.id: High Overall Failed Page Action Rate
incidentrule.description: The overall failed page action rate exceeds the configured threshold.
The host in question consumes an excessive amount of CPU time
The physically available memory is low
the available total memory of the host is low
The available network bandwidth is continuously low. Too much traffic on the host.
Diskspace needed for stable operations is low (var space, temp space
the root disk is nearly out of free space
Too much System CPU time indicates a problem at the machine like too much swapping.

condition.refmeasure: Web Page Requests by URI (PurePath Response Time;PurePaths;PurePath Response Time)

incidentrule.description: Orderly shutdown of Application Process/Agent.
Custom user created incidents for deployment.

The average response time (median) is significantly higher than expected. Although the observed response time might be still acceptable for users, this behavior is typically caused by application or infrastructure problems and reduces the maximum throughput you can achieve.

incidentrule.id: Response time degraded for slow requests
incidentrule.description: The observed response time for the slowest 10% of requests has increased significantly. This results in poor user experience and can be caused by application or infrastructure problems.
The rate of failed transactions is significantly higher than expected.
The Application Process has had significant suspension time for a sustained period of time due to spending considerable amount of it's execution time on Garbage Collection.
The Host has had a high CPU usage for a sustained period of time.
The Host has had at least one network interface with high bandwidth usage for a sustained period of time.
The Host has at least one disk with little space available.
The Host has had memory with little space available or considerable amount of page faults for a sustained period of time.

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from Microsoft Windows Systems (e.g. % Processor Time, Memory, AvailableKBytes, ...)

measure.description: The amount of physical memory, in bytes, available to processes currently running. It is calculated by adding the amount of space on the Zeroed, Free, and Standby memory lists. Free memory is ready for use; Zeroed memory consists of pages of memory filled with zeros to prevent subsequent processes from seeing data used by a previous process; Standby memory is memory that has been removed from a process' working set (its physical memory) on route to disk, but is still available to be recalled. It displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.
The percentage of time the processor is idle during the sample interval

The percentage of elapsed time that the processor spends to execute a non-idle thread. It is calculated by measuring the duration of the idle thread is active in the sample interval, and subtracting that time from interval duration. Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run. This counter is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed during the sample interval. It is calculated by monitoring the time that the service is inactive, and subtracting that value from 100%.

The percentage of elapsed time the processor spends in the user mode. User mode is a restricted processing mode designed for applications, environment subsystems, and integral subsystems. The alternative, privileged mode, is designed for operating system components and allows direct access to hardware and all memory. The operating system switches application threads to privileged mode to access operating system services. It displays the average busy time as a percentage of the sample time.
The rate of read operations on the disk.
The rate of write operations on the disk.
It shows the unallocated space, in megabytes, on the disk drive in megabytes. One megabyte is equal to 1,048,576 bytes.
Percentage of total usable space on all logical disc drives that is free.

The rate at which pages are read from disk to resolve hard page faults. Hard page faults occur when a process refers to a page in virtual memory that is not in its working set or elsewhere in physical memory, and must be retrieved from disk. When a page is faulted, the system tries to read multiple contiguous pages into memory to maximize the benefit of the read operation.

The rate at which pages are written to disk to free up space in physical memory. Pages are written back to disk only if they are changed in physical memory, so they are likely to hold data, not code. A high rate of pages output might indicate a memory shortage. Windows writes more pages back to disk to free up space when physical memory is in short supply.

The average number of pages faulted per second. It is measured in number of pages faulted per second because only one page is faulted in each fault operation, hence this is also equal to the number of page fault operations. This counter includes both hard faults (those that require disk access) and soft faults (where the faulted page is found elsewhere in physical memory.) Most processors can handle large numbers of soft faults without significant consequence. However, hard faults, which require disk access, can cause significant delays.
The rate at which bytes are transferred from the disk during read operations.
The rate at which bytes are transferred to the disk during write operations.
The number of processes at the time of data collection. This is an instantaneous count, not an average over the time interval.

The current size, in bytes, of the Working Set of all processes. The Working Set is the set of memory pages touched recently by the threads in the process. If free memory is above a threshold, pages are left in the Working Set of a process even if they are not in use. When free memory falls below a threshold, pages are trimmed from Working Sets. If they are needed they will then be soft-faulted back into the Working Set before leaving main memory.

The number of threads in the processor queue. It shows ready threads only, not threads that are running. There is a single queue for processor time even on computers with multiple processors. Therefore, if a computer has multiple processors, you need to divide this value by the number of processors servicing the workload.

The amount of memory resources that the scheduler thinks the VM/resource pool should receive. This is calculated based on the current estimated memory demand and resource policies (i.e. reservation, limit and shares) set for all VM/resource pool in the host/cluster.
Amount of additional host memory allocated to the virtual machine. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
Amount of additional host memory allocated to the virtual machine. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of additional host memory allocated to the virtual machine. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Portion of memory in use as a percentage of total configured or available memory. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
Portion of memory in use as a percentage of total configured or available memory. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Portion of memory in use as a percentage of total configured or available memory. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory used by the VMkernel. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
Amount of memory used by the VMkernel. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory used by the VMkernel. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory reserved by the virtual machines. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 2 or higher.
Amount of memory that is shared between virtual machines. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 2 or higher.
Amount of memory that is shared between virtual machines. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is shared between virtual machines. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that can be swapped. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that can be swapped. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that can be swapped. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 2 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped in. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 2 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped in. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped in. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 2 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped out. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 2 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped out. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is swapped out. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is zeroed out. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 2 or higher.
Amount of memory that is zeroed out. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Amount of memory that is zeroed out. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Rate at which data is received in the performance interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Rate at which data is transmitted in the performance interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
The sum of data transmitted and received for all the NIC instances of the host or virtual machine. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
Number of packets received in the performance interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Number of packets transmitted in the performance interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Amount of data read from disk during the defined interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Amount of data written to disk during the defined interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time taken to complete a command from the physical device. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time taken to complete a read from the physical device. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time taken to complete a write from the physical device. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Total size of data read and written for all disk instances of the host or virtual machine. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
Average time spent in the ESX Server VMkernel per command. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time spent in the ESX Server VMkernel per read. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time spent in the ESX Server VMkernel per write. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Number of times data was read from disk during the defined interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Number of times data was written to disk in the defined interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Number of disk commands aborted during the defined interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Number of bus resets during the defined interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Number of disk commands issued during the defined interval. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time spent in the ESX Server VMkernel queue per command. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time spent in the ESX Server VMkernel queue per read. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time spent in the ESX Server VMkernel queue per write. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time taken for disk commands by a Guest OS, the sum of kernelCommandLatency and physical deviceCommandLatency. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time taken for a read by a Guest OS, the sum of kernelReadLatency and physical deviceReadLatency. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Average time taken for a write by a Guest OS, the sum of kernelWriteLatency and physical deviceWriteLatency. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Resource CPU usage. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
Resource CPU usage. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
Resource CPU usage. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Resource CPU usage. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
Total time elapsed since last system startup. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
The average active time for the CPU over the past fifteen minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
measure.metricgroupid: VMware Virtual Machine - CPU Resource Utilization

measure.description: The average active time for the CPU over the past minute. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The average active time for the CPU over the past five minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The average runtime for the CPU over the past fifteen minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The average runtime for the CPU over the past minute. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The average runtime for the CPU over the past five minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The peak active time for the CPU over the past fifteen minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The peak active time for the CPU over the past minute. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The peak active time for the CPU over the past five minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The peak runtime for the CPU over the past fifteen minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The peak runtime for the CPU over the past five minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The sample period. The sample CPU count. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
measure.metricgroupid: VMware Virtual Machine - CPU Resource Utilization

measure.description: VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
measure.metricgroupid: VMware Virtual Machine - CPU Resource Utilization

measure.description: The scheduling limit over the past fifteen minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The scheduling limit over the past minute. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.

measure.description: The scheduling limit over the past five minutes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher.
measure.metricgroupid: VMware Virtual Machine - CPU Resource Utilization

measure.description: The amount of CPU resources that the scheduler devotes to the virtual machine. This is calculated based on the current estimated CPU demand and resource policies (reservation, limit, and shares) set for all virtual machines in the host or cluster. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher (internal)
CPU usage in MHz over the interval of collection. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher
CPU usage in MHz over the interval of collection. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher
CPU usage in MHz over the interval of collection. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher
CPU usage as a percentage over the interval of collection. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 1 or higher.
CPU usage as a percentage over the interval of collection. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
CPU usage as a percentage over the interval of collection. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 4 or higher.
CPU time that is extra. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher
CPU time that is guaranteed (also called reserved) for the virtual machine. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher (deprecated)
Deprecated, this metric is only available for consistency. Use 'Ready CPU Time Percent' instaed. CPU time spent in ready state. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher
CPU time spent in ready state. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher
CPU time spent on system processes. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher
CPU time that is used. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher
Total time that a virtual CPU is not runnable. It could be idle (halted) or waiting for an external event such as I/O. VirtualCenter statistics level must be set to 3 or higher

mastermonitorconfig.desc: Reads out PerfMon information from Microsoft Windows Systems (e.g. % Processor Time, Memory, AvailableKBytes, ...)

measure.description: The ratio of pysical memory in use to the size of the paging file.

The amount of physical memory, in bytes, available to processes currently running. It is calculated by adding the amount of space on the Zeroed, Free, and Standby memory lists. Free memory is ready for use; Zeroed memory consists of pages of memory filled with zeros to prevent subsequent processes from seeing data used by a previous process; Standby memory is memory that has been removed from a process' working set (its physical memory) on route to disk, but is still available to be recalled. It displays the last observed value only; it is not an average.
The number of requests outstanding on the disk at the time the performance data is collected.
The rate of read operations on the disk.
The rate of write operations on the disk.
It shows the unallocated space, in megabytes, on the disk drive in megabytes. One megabyte is equal to 1,048,576 bytes.
Percentage of total usable space on all logical disc drives that is free.

The rate at which pages are read from disk to resolve hard page faults. Hard page faults occur when a process refers to a page in virtual memory that is not in its working set or elsewhere in physical memory, and must be retrieved from disk. When a page is faulted, the system tries to read multiple contiguous pages into memory to maximize the benefit of the read operation.

The rate at which pages are written to disk to free up space in physical memory. Pages are written back to disk only if they are changed in physical memory, so they are likely to hold data, not code. A high rate of pages output might indicate a memory shortage. Windows writes more pages back to disk to free up space when physical memory is in short supply.

The average number of pages faulted per second. It is measured in number of pages faulted per second because only one page is faulted in each fault operation, hence this is also equal to the number of page fault operations. This counter includes both hard faults (those that require disk access) and soft faults (where the faulted page is found elsewhere in physical memory.) Most processors can handle large numbers of soft faults without significant consequence. However, hard faults, which require disk access, can cause significant delays.
The rate at which bytes are transferred from the disk during read operations.
The rate at which bytes are transferred to the disk during write operations.
The number of processes at the time of data collection. This is an instantaneous count, not an average over the time interval.

The current size, in bytes, of the Working Set of all processes. The Working Set is the set of memory pages touched recently by the threads in the process. If free memory is above a threshold, pages are left in the Working Set of a process even if they are not in use. When free memory falls below a threshold, pages are trimmed from Working Sets. If they are needed they will then be soft-faulted back into the Working Set before leaving main memory.

The number of threads in the processor queue. It shows ready threads only, not threads that are running. There is a single queue for processor time even on computers with multiple processors. Therefore, if a computer has multiple processors, you need to divide this value by the number of processors servicing the workload.
The percentage of time the processor is idle during the sample interval
The rate at which the processor receives hardware interrupts.

The percentage of elapsed time that the processor spends to execute a non-idle thread. It is calculated by measuring the duration of the idle thread is active in the sample interval, and subtracting that time from interval duration. Each processor has an idle thread that consumes cycles when no other threads are ready to run. This counter is the primary indicator of processor activity, and displays the average percentage of busy time observed during the sample interval. It is calculated by monitoring the time that the service is inactive, and subtracting that value from 100%.

The percentage of elapsed time the processor spends in the user mode. User mode is a restricted processing mode designed for applications, environment subsystems, and integral subsystems. The alternative, privileged mode, is designed for operating system components and allows direct access to hardware and all memory. The operating system switches application threads to privileged mode to access operating system services. It displays the average busy time as a percentage of the sample time.
